metadata.title: Present Perfect: Life Experiences
metadata.keywords: present-perfect, life-experiences, travel, ever, never, been

objectives.objective: Use present perfect to talk about life experiences without specific time references
Distinguish between present perfect and past simple
Ask and answer questions about experiences using 'Have you ever...?'

stage.name: Lead-in
stage.description:
Ask a somatic grounding question to connect body ‚Üí mind ‚Üí language. Example: "Before we begin, take a moment... Can you notice where in your body you hold memories of your favorite travel experience? Your chest? Your hands? Just notice, no need to explain yet."
Then transition: "Today we'll explore how to talk about life experiences in English - moments that have shaped who you are."

stage.name: Pre task A (Activate)
stage.description:
Elicit prior knowledge about travel and life experiences using Socratic questions. Use carousel for memory retrieval options.
Sample carousel questions: - Card 1: "What's a place you've been to that changed your perspective?" - Card 2: "Think of an experience you've had that you'll never forget. What made it special?" - Card 3: "Have you ever tried something completely outside your comfort zone?"
Follow up with probing questions: - "What made that experience meaningful?" - "How did it change you?" - "Would you do it again?"
Listen for their use of past tense and gently notice it (without correcting yet).

stage.name: Pre task B (Model)

dialogue.title: A Conversation About Travel Experiences
dialogue.context: Two friends, Layla and Hassan, are having coffee and sharing travel stories.
dialogue.speaker: I've been to so many countries, but Morocco was the most magical. Have you ever been there?
No, I haven't been to Morocco yet, but I've always wanted to go. What did you do there?
We explored the markets in Marrakech, tried amazing food, and stayed in a traditional riad. I've never experienced anything like it! The colors, the sounds, the smells - everything was so alive.
That sounds incredible. I've traveled around Europe quite a bit, but I've never been to North Africa. Have you ever gotten lost in a new place?
Oh yes! In Fes, actually. We wandered through the medina for hours. It was frustrating at first, but then we just... let go. Some of the best moments have happened when I've been completely lost.
I know that feeling. I've had similar experiences in Istanbul. Getting lost is sometimes the best way to find something unexpected.

stage.conceptChecks:
After presenting the dialogue, use concept check questions: - "When did Layla go to Morocco - do we know exactly when?" (No - that's the point of present perfect!) - "Has Hassan been to Morocco?" (No, not yet) - "What's more important in their conversation - the specific time, or the experience itself?" (The experience) - "Notice how they ask questions: 'Have you ever...?' - what are they asking about?" (Life experiences in general, not a specific moment)
Use notice boxes to draw attention to the structure.

grammarFocus.explanation:
Present the grammar using CARD layout:
**Card 1: Form** Affirmative: I/You/We/They + have + past participle He/She/It + has + past participle
Examples: - I have been to Japan. - She has tried sushi. - They have visited 15 countries.
**Card 2: Questions** Have + subject + past participle? Has + he/she/it + past participle?
Examples: - Have you ever been abroad? - Has he ever tried falafel? - Have they ever seen the Northern Lights?
**Card 3: Negative** haven't / hasn't + past participle
Examples: - I haven't been to Egypt yet. - She hasn't tried rock climbing. - We haven't finished exploring Asia.
**Card 4: Time Expressions** Use notice boxes to highlight these patterns: - ever (in questions): "Have you ever...?" - never (negative meaning): "I've never been..." - yet (expected to happen): "I haven't gone yet." - already (happened sooner than expected): "I've already visited!" - before (at some point in the past): "Have you been here before?"
**Card 5: Present Perfect vs Past Simple** Use a comparison card: Present Perfect ‚Üí Focus on EXPERIENCE (time not important/unknown) - "I've been to Paris." (In my life, at some point)
Past Simple ‚Üí Focus on SPECIFIC PAST TIME - "I went to Paris last year." (Specific: last year)
Notice box: "If you mention WHEN (yesterday, last week, in 2020), use past simple. If you're talking about life experience without 'when', use present perfect."
grammarFocus.examples: Provide multiple examples using learning cards: - "I've eaten street food in Bangkok, but I've never tried insects." - "Have you ever broken a bone?" - "She's written three books, but she hasn't published them yet." - "We've studied English for years, and we've already passed B1 level."

pronunciationFocus.feature: Weak forms and contractions in present perfect
pronunciationFocus.guidance:
Use think prompts for noticing: "Listen carefully to how native speakers say 'have' and 'has' in sentences..."
**Focus areas:**
1. **Contractions** (very common in speech): - I have ‚Üí I've /a…™v/ - You have ‚Üí You've /juÀêv/ - She has ‚Üí She's / ÉiÀêz/ - They have ‚Üí They've /√∞e…™v/
2. **Weak form of 'have'** in questions: - "Have you ever...?" ‚Üí /h…ôv/ (not /h√¶v/) - Sounds like "H…ô-vyou-ever"
3. **Connected speech**: - "Have you ever been" ‚Üí "Havyou-ever-been" (words flow together) - "I've been to" ‚Üí "I've-been-t…ô" ('to' becomes /t…ô/)
Model examples with dialogue boxes, then ask the student to repeat. Use sentence stems like: - "I've been to ___" - "Have you ever ___?" - "She's never ___"
Encourage natural rhythm, not word-by-word pronunciation.

taskSetup.scenario: You and a new friend are getting to know each other. You're sharing stories about your life experiences to find common ground and interesting differences.
taskSetup.roles:
Assign roles: - Student: Shares their real or imagined life experiences - You (Nour): Will ask follow-up questions and share experiences too, modeling the language
Provide thinking time: "Take 30 seconds to think about 3-4 interesting experiences you've had (or would like to have had). They could be related to: travel, food, learning, challenges, adventures, or meeting people."
taskSetup.support:
Provide sentence stems carousel: - "I've been to ___, and it was ___" - "I've never ___, but I'd like to" - "Have you ever ___?" - "The most ___ thing I've ever done is ___" - "I've tried ___ several times"
Vocabulary support carousel (words they can use): - Experiences: unforgettable, meaningful, life-changing, challenging, rewarding - Travel: journey, destination, explore, wander, discover - Feelings: amazed, inspired, nervous, proud, grateful

activity.description:
Facilitate a natural conversation about life experiences. You participate as well, modeling the structure.
Start with: "So, tell me - have you ever done something that really surprised you?"
Monitor and note errors WITHOUT interrupting. Pay attention to: - Do they use present perfect or past simple? (Common error: "I never went" instead of "I've never been") - Do they use correct past participles? (Common error: "I have go" instead of "I have gone") - Do they ask questions correctly? ("You have ever...?" instead of "Have you ever...?")
Encourage extended turns with prompts like: - "Tell me more about that..." - "What was that like?" - "How did you feel?"
Let the conversation flow naturally for 5-8 exchanges.

stage.name: Reporting
stage.reflection:
Have the student reflect on their performance using self-assessment widget:
"Let's pause for a moment. How confident do you feel about using the present perfect now?"
Then ask metacognitive questions: - "What went well in our conversation?" - "Was there a moment where you weren't sure which tense to use?" - "Which structure felt most natural: statements, questions, or negatives?" - "What's one thing you learned about yourself through this topic?"

stage.name: Feedback
stage.feedbackGuidance:
Provide corrections using highlights (hl-feedback, hl-grammar). Focus on 2-3 priority areas.
Use varied correction strategies: - If they said "I never been to..." ‚Üí Recast: "Ah yes, you've never been there, interesting!" - If they consistently use past simple instead ‚Üí Use a notice box with the rule - If past participles are wrong ‚Üí Use explicit correction with a grammar card
Example feedback card: **Card: What you did well ‚ú®** - You asked great questions using "Have you ever...?" - Your pronunciation of contractions was natural - You shared experiences with good detail
**Card: Let's polish this üîß** [Use hl-grammar highlighting] Instead of: "I never went to Morocco" Try: "I've never been to Morocco"
Remember: 'never' pairs with present perfect for life experiences!
**Card: Your goal for next time üéØ** Practice using "yet" and "already" in your responses. Try this: "I haven't been there yet, but I've already planned my trip!"
End with specific praise: "I loved how you described feeling 'alive' in the markets - that's exactly the kind of sensory detail that makes language come to life!"

lesson.culturalContext:
When discussing travel experiences, be mindful of diverse economic contexts. Not everyone has had opportunities to travel internationally, and that's completely okay. Frame questions inclusively: "experiences" can include trying new foods in your city, learning a skill, meeting someone new, or reading a book that changed your view. The grammar works the same way!
Encourage students to share authentically, whether their experiences are grand adventures or quiet personal moments.

commonErrors.error: Using past simple instead of present perfect: "I never went" ‚Üí "I've never been"
Wrong past participle: "I have go" ‚Üí "I have gone"
Question word order: "You have ever...?" ‚Üí "Have you ever...?"
Using present perfect with specific time: "I have been there yesterday" ‚Üí "I went there yesterday"
